poem:
Title: The Silent Currents of Sceptered Isle

The nation, a cradle of whispered truths,
Where Labour's lead, a gossamer shroud.
Rochdale's lesson; discovered in squalid booths,
Rings out her wake-up call, urgent and loud.

In the haze of Israel-Hamas war's strain,
Britain's heart wavers not, from either vein.
The majority carry, silent and sane,
Opinions layered like quiet rain.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A lesson and a wake-up call from Rochdale: Labour has become too complacent about its big poll lead | Martin Kettle More than four months into the Israel-Hamas war, and after the Labour party’s Rochdale byelection candidate shambles, it can come as something of a surprise to be reminded that most domestic opinion in Britain is emphatically not polarised between uncompromisingly pro-Israel and uncompromisingly pro-Hamas positions. On the contrary, the majority of the public do". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
